> -----Original Message-----
> From: Vladimir R. Bossicard [mailto:vladimir@...] 
> 
> > These problems can be mitigated by including thorough postcondition 
> > and invariant validation at the end of east test.
> 
> If the problem is only potential (and may only hit you once a 
> year) a normal developer (myself included) will most likely 
> not put the extra effort to write
> pre- and postconditions for every test/testcase.  And when it 
> finally hits you, you're sure to spend hours (if not days) 
> finding and fixing the problem.

Mitigated, but not eliminated. Thorough postcondition validation is for
the purpose of proving correct operation. A side benefit is catching
invalid state before it is discovered downstream. Low-level unit tests
have fewer interdependencies between tests simply by their nature.
Interdependencies become an issue as the scope of the tests creeps
outward toward the system level. The design decisions that went into
JUnit presuppose lever level testing and tend to become restrictive as
you try to grow the tests' scope outward.
